explanation:
- OS_object_iter_t: The iterator struct definition is needed to know the types and initial/valid ranges of fields used by the loop (limit, base, match, arg and the token member). Whether obj_idx or limit are signed/unsigned and their initialization affect whether the loop condition can be invariant.

- (token) type inside OS_object_iter_t (fields: obj_idx, obj_id): The concrete type and field definitions for iter->token (e.g., obj_idx and obj_id) are required to determine how ++iter->token.obj_idx behaves (wrap/overflow semantics, width) and whether token is modified elsewhere; this directly affects whether got_next can change across iterations.

- OS_common_record_t: The record structure (including the active_id field) is required to know what OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET returns and whether record->active_id can cause iter->token.obj_id (and thus got_next) to change.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: The macro/function that maps (iter->base, iter->token) to a record must be inspected to determine if it can return NULL, if it can fail, or if it has side-effects that influence loop progress. Its semantics determine whether the loop body can make got_next true.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: The static call graph indicates this helper may be invoked (likely inside OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET). Its behavior (how it computes indexes from tokens) affects whether successive ++obj_idx will access different records and thus whether the match/test can ever succeed — required to decide if the do-while condition is invariant.

- match callback type/prototype (iter->match): The signature and return type of the match callback (and whether it may be NULL) are required to determine how iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record) can change got_next. Also needed to know whether the callback may have side effects that change iterator state.

- OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED: The constant assigned to iter->token.obj_id at function start is required for understanding initial state and for reasoning about whether the loop ever observes or produces a different obj_id value (relevant to whether got_next becomes true).

Together these symbols define the data types, macros, and callback behavior that determine whether the controlling expression (!got_next) can change between iterations (i.e., is non-invariant) or is effectively constant, so they are necessary to determine compliance with the MISRA rule.
